title: Bypassing the fix of #503922

vulnerability_information:
Hi,

Just bypassed the fix of open redirect.

See comments for more details.

 Best Regards,
-MO

## Impact

Open redirection
vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,

Just bypassed the fix of open redirect.

See comments for more details.

Open redirection

activities.message:
This presubmission check muddles up the sub. Anyways...This is the bypass of the report #503922. I just figured out by putting extra %2f we can bypass the fix.
#POC url
https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=%2f%2f%2fevil.com%2f&op=login&login=password=&profile=0

You'd be redirected to evil.com



Best Regards,
-MO

activities.message:
BTW, just read https://discourse.tt-rss.org/t/open-redirect-via-public-php/2077.

IMO open redirect isn't a moron type low risk issue. :p Without Phissing, a hacker can redirect users to a site while they would auto download the malware in their computer, and the users wouldn't mind clicking the link since the domain would be trusted.

Would want you guys to see this too.
https://youtu.be/4Jk_I-cw4WE

Best Regards,
-MO

Thanks for your report! We need some more information before we can adequately review this report. Is it possible you could provide a clear step-by-step PoC showing your vulnerability?  Thanks again for your report and we hope to hear back from you soon.

Kind regards.

activities.message:
Report at https://hackerone.com/reports/503922, hacker  reported open redirect issue where a hacker had the ability to redirect users from a trusted site to a non trusted site.
His POC URL was:
https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=http%3a%2f%2fevil.com%2f&op=login&login=password=&profile=0
 where the vulnerable parameter was `return=http%3a%2f%2fevil.com%2f&`. 

This was fixed and disclosed publicly.

So I figured out by adding extra %2f in the return paramters value, it is possible to bypass the fix.
so the final url looked like this:

https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=`%2f%2f%2fevil.com%2f`&op=login&login=password=&profile=0
. 


The POC steps to reproduce this issue are very simple.

1) Click and go to :

#
    https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=`%2f%2f%2fevil.com%2f`&op=login&login=password=&profile=0

This would redirect to you the domain set in the return parameter, which in this case, as is readable and intentionally tried to demonstrate as easy to detect - is evil.com.


###Side-Note
Learning about the fix of the original report (#503922), I knew that open redirects was called an issue for morons, however, I strongly disagree. Beyond phissing, it has a other impacts too such as downloading malicious softwares and files such as html (because it sometimes could be used to do xss or csrf if web app is using device based nonce tokens, exe, cmd etc. This poses a meduim risk and could also have an escalation based on where and how this comes up.

Thus, it would be awesome maybe if I present the following video link too on open redirects:

https://youtu.be/4Jk_I-cw4WE



Hope this elobrates it well. :)

Best Regards,
-MO
activities.markdown_message:
Report at https://hackerone.com/reports/503922, hacker reported open redirect issue where a hacker had the ability to redirect users from a trusted site to a non trusted site.
His POC URL was:
https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=http%3a%2f%2fevil.com%2f&op=login&login=password=&profile=0
where the vulnerable parameter was return=http%3a%2f%2fevil.com%2f&.

This was fixed and disclosed publicly.

So I figured out by adding extra %2f in the return paramters value, it is possible to bypass the fix.
so the final url looked like this:

https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=%60%2f%2f%2fevil.com%2f%60&op=login&login=password=&profile=0
.

The POC steps to reproduce this issue are very simple.

1) Click and go to :

https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=`%2f%2f%2fevil.com%2f`&op=login&login=password=&profile=0

This would redirect to you the domain set in the return parameter, which in this case, as is readable and intentionally tried to demonstrate as easy to detect - is evil.com.

Side-Note

Learning about the fix of the original report (#503922), I knew that open redirects was called an issue for morons, however, I strongly disagree. Beyond phissing, it has a other impacts too such as downloading malicious softwares and files such as html (because it sometimes could be used to do xss or csrf if web app is using device based nonce tokens, exe, cmd etc. This poses a meduim risk and could also have an escalation based on where and how this comes up.

Thus, it would be awesome maybe if I present the following video link too on open redirects:

https://youtu.be/4Jk_I-cw4WE

Hope this elobrates it well. :)

Best Regards,
-MO

activities.message:
I just mistakely typed `  in the poc url. 
The poc url and steps would be:

1) Click here instead,

https://tt.hboeck.de/public.php?return=%2f%2f%2fevil.com%2f&op=login&login=password=&profile=0

2) Notice that you're redirected to evil.com


-MO

activities.message:
I solved this now for my domain by putting it behind a login.

Given the level of the discussion at tt-rss I'm not willing to engage with them, but feel free to discuss this with them and convince them to do a proper fix.

activities.message:
I think this would be a post based open redirect now. I'd agree this is a nice fix and post based open redirects do not pose security risk and are just informative. 

Lets disclose the summary only?

Best Regards,
-MO
activities.markdown_message:
I think this would be a post based open redirect now. I'd agree this is a nice fix and post based open redirects do not pose security risk and are just informative.

summaries.content: Paramter's value set to %2f%2fevil.com redirected to evil.com. This was patched and the fix was bypassed by adding extra %2f!
summaries.content_html: Paramter's value set to %2f%2fevil.com redirected to evil.com. This was patched and the fix was bypassed by adding extra %2f!
